LINUX FILE PERMISSIONS

$ utku@scw-712067:~$ ls -al total 48 drwxr-xr-x 6 utku utku 4096 Apr 29 09:54 . drwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Apr 23 20:05 .. -rw——- 1 utku utku 476 Apr 23 20:55 .bash_history -rw-r–r– 1 utku utku 220 Apr 23 20:05 .bash_logout -rw-r–r– 1 utku utku 3771 Apr 23 20:05 .bashrc drwx—— 2 utku utku 4096 Apr 23 20:06 .cache -rw——- 1 utku utku 43 Apr 23 20:21 .lesshst drwxrwxr-x 2 utku utku 4096 Apr 29 09:54 linux drwxrwxr-x 2 utku utku 4096 Apr 29 09:54 .nano -rw-r–r– 1 utku utku 655 Apr 23 20:05 .profile drwx—— 2 utku utku 4096 Apr 23 20:54 .ssh

-rw-r–r– (let’s handle one of them) | V first letter means directory or file. d:directory -:file

now we can seperate these permissions into 4 groups.

  • rw- r– r– directory or file owner group everyone

permissions owner group
drwxr-xr-x 3 root root 4096 Apr 23 20:05 .. -rw-r–r– 1 utku utku 655 Apr 23 20:05 .profile

Octal Permissions

-rw-r–r– is equal to ‘644’ in octal permissions

r = 4 w = 2 x = 1 - = 0

rw- = 6 r– = 4 r– = 4

-rwxrwxrwx = 777 drwxr-xr-x = 755 -rw——- = 600

$ ls -al ~ … -rw——- 1 utku utku 476 Apr 23 20:55 .bash_history …

This file’s owner and group are named ‘utku’.

If we change group of file to ‘root’, utku user can still read file. Because owner has read access (rw-)

$ sudo chgrp root .bash_history $ cat .bash_history

But if we change owner of file to ‘root’, utku user cannot read that file. $ sudo chown root .bash_history $ cat .bash_history cat: .bash_history: Permission denied.

(dont forget to revert owner and group back) $ sudo chgrp utku .bash_history $ sudo chown utku .bash_history
